TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit MenuStrip extends System.Windows.Forms.ToolStrip

Docs.summary: Provides a menu system for a form.

remarks.format:
## Remarks MenuStrip is the top-level container that supersedes <xref:System.Windows.Forms.MainMenu>. It also provides key handling and multiple document interface (MDI) features. Functionally, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripDropDownItem> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem> work along with MenuStrip, although they are derived from <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripItem>.
The following items are specifically designed to work seamlessly with both <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripSystemRenderer> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProfessionalRenderer> in all orientations. They are available by default at design time for the MenuStrip control:
- <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem>
- <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripTextBox>
- <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripComboBox>
The MenuStrip control represents the container for the menu structure of a form. You can add <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem> objects to the MenuStrip that represent the individual menu commands in the menu structure. Each <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem> can be a command for your application or a parent menu for other submenu items.
Although MenuStrip replaces and adds functionality to the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.MainMenu> control of previous versions, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.MainMenu> is retained for both backward compatibility and future use if you choose.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates a MenuStrip in a multiple-document interface (MDI) scenario.
[!code-cs[System.Windows.Forms.ToolStrip.Misc#10](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/t-system.windows.forms.m_2_1.cs)] [!code-vb[System.Windows.Forms.ToolStrip.Misc#10](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/t-system.windows.forms.m_2_1.vb)]

Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Use this constructor to create a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.MenuStrip> to which you can add <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem> objects.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates the MenuStrip constructor. This example is part of a larger example provided for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripPanel> class.
[!code-cs[System.Windows.Forms.ToolStrip.Misc#12](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/m-system.windows.forms.m_2_1.cs)] [!code-vb[System.Windows.Forms.ToolStrip.Misc#12](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/m-system.windows.forms.m_2_1.vb)]

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the supports overflow functionality.
Docs.value: if the supports overflow functionality; otherwise, . The default is .

remarks.format: ## Remarks The overflow feature moves menu items to a drop-down menu when there is not enough room to display them in a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.MenuStrip>. When you set the CanOverflow property to `true`, you must also enable overflow for specific menu items by setting the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem.Overflow%2A?displayProperty=fullName> property. By default, menu items are not displayed if they cannot fit within the available space.

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig virtual instance class System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleObject CreateAccessibilityInstance() cil managed

Docs.summary: Creates a new accessibility object for the control.

remarks.format:
## Remarks If you do not explicitly call the CreateAccessibilityInstance method, it will be called when the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.AccessibilityObject%2A?displayProperty=fullName> property is referenced.
> [!NOTE] > To get or set the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.AccessibilityObject%2A?displayProperty=fullName> property, you must add a reference to the `Accessibility` assembly installed with the .NET Framework.
For a code example of using CreateAccessibilityInstance, see <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.CreateAccessibilityInstance%2A?displayProperty=fullName>.

remarks.format: ## Remarks Use the CreateDefaultItem method to add a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem> with commonly used characteristics to a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.MenuStrip>.

Docs.summary: Gets the spacing, in pixels, between the left, right, top, and bottom edges of the from the edges of the form.
Docs.value: A that represents the spacing. The default is `{Left=6, Top=2, Right=0, Bottom=2}`.

remarks.format: ## Remarks Use the DefaultPadding property to set the interior space between controls. When a control is a container of items, padding represents the space from the edge of the container.

Docs.summary: Gets a value indicating whether ToolTips are shown for the by default.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The DefaultShowItemToolTips property always returns `false` because typically, ToolTips are not used for menus or menu items.

Docs.summary: Gets the horizontal and vertical dimensions, in pixels, of the when it is first created.
Docs.value: A <xref:System.Drawing.Point.%23ctor%2A> value representing the horizontal and vertical dimensions, in pixels. The default is 200 x 21 pixels.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the visibility of the grip used to reposition the control.
Docs.value: One of the values. The default is .

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the that is used to display a list of Multiple-document interface (MDI) child forms.
Docs.value: A that represents the menu item displaying a list of MDI child forms that are open in the application.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Use the MdiWindowListItem property to designate or discover which <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem> displays MDI children.
Use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.MenuStrip.MenuActivate> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.MenuStrip.MenuDeactivate> events on child menus to reflect changes to the value of MdiWindowListItem.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates the MdiWindowListItem property. This example is part of a larger example provided for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripPanel> class.
[!code-cs[System.Windows.Forms.ToolStrip.Misc#12](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.windows.forms.m_43_1.cs)] [!code-vb[System.Windows.Forms.ToolStrip.Misc#12](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.windows.forms.m_43_1.vb)]

Docs.summary: Occurs when the user accesses the menu with the keyboard or mouse.

remarks.format:
## Remarks When activated by the ALT key, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.MenuStrip> or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStrip> typically neither take nor remove the focus from the control that currently has the focus. If there is a control hosted within the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.MenuStrip> or a drop-down of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.MenuStrip>, the control gains focus when the user presses the TAB key. In general, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.GotFocus>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.LostFocus>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Enter>, and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Leave> events of <xref:System.Windows.Forms.MenuStrip> might not be raised when they are activated by the keyboard. In such cases, use the MenuActivate and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.MenuStrip.MenuDeactivate> events instead.
For more information about handling events, see [Events](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
## Examples The following code example demonstrates the use of this member. In the example, an event handler reports on the occurrence of the MenuActivate event. This report helps you to learn when the event occurs and can assist you in debugging. To report on multiple events or on events that occur frequently, consider replacing <xref:System.Windows.Forms.MessageBox.Show%2A?displayProperty=fullName> with <xref:System.Console.WriteLine%2A?displayProperty=fullName> or appending the message to a multiline <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TextBox>.
To run the example code, paste it into a project that contains an instance of type <xref:System.Windows.Forms.MenuStrip> named `MenuStrip1`. Then ensure that the event handler is associated with the MenuActivate event.
[!code-cs[System.Windows.Forms.EventExamples#489](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/e-system.windows.forms.m_7_1.cs)] [!code-vb[System.Windows.Forms.EventExamples#489](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/e-system.windows.forms.m_7_1.vb)]

## Remarks When activated by the ALT key, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.MenuStrip> or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStrip> typically neither take nor remove the focus from the control that currently has the focus. If there is a control hosted within the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.MenuStrip> or a drop-down of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.MenuStrip>, the control gains focus when the user presses the TAB key. In general, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.GotFocus>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.LostFocus>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Enter>, and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Leave> events of <xref:System.Windows.Forms.MenuStrip> might not be raised when they are activated by the keyboard. In such cases, use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.MenuStrip.MenuActivate> and MenuDeactivate events instead.
For more information about handling events, see [Events](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
## Examples The following code example demonstrates the use of this member. In the example, an event handler reports on the occurrence of the MenuDeactivate event. This report helps you to learn when the event occurs and can assist you in debugging. To report on multiple events or on events that occur frequently, consider replacing <xref:System.Windows.Forms.MessageBox.Show%2A?displayProperty=fullName> with <xref:System.Console.WriteLine%2A?displayProperty=fullName> or appending the message to a multiline <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TextBox>.
To run the example code, paste it into a project that contains an instance of type <xref:System.Windows.Forms.MenuStrip> named `MenuStrip1`. Then ensure that the event handler is associated with the MenuDeactivate event.
[!code-cs[System.Windows.Forms.EventExamples#490](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/e-system.windows.forms.m_4_1.cs)] [!code-vb[System.Windows.Forms.EventExamples#490](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/e-system.windows.forms.m_4_1.vb)]

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig newslot virtual instance void OnMenuActivate(class System.EventArgs e) cil managed

Docs.param: An <xref:System.EventArgs> that contains the event data.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate. For more information, see [Events](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
The OnMenuActivate method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate. This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate. For more information, see [Events](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
The OnMenuDeactivate method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate. This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.

MemberSignature.Value: protected override void WndProc (ref System.Windows.Forms.Message m);
.method familyhidebysig virtual instance void WndProc(valuetype System.Windows.Forms.Message m) cil managed

remarks.format:
## Remarks All messages are sent to the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.WndProc%2A> method after getting filtered through the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.PreProcessMessage%2A> method.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.WndProc%2A> method corresponds exactly to the Windows `WindowProc` function. For more information about processing Windows messages, see the `WindowProc` function documentation in the Windows Platform SDK reference located in the MSDN library at http://msdn.microsoft.com/library.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates overriding the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.WndProc%2A> method to handle operating system messages identified in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Message> structure. The WM_ACTIVATEAPP operating system message is handled in this example to know when another application is becoming active. Refer to the Platform SDK documentation reference located in the MSDN library at http://msdn.microsoft.com/library to understand the available <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Message.Msg%2A?displayProperty=fullName>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Message.LParam%2A?displayProperty=fullName>, and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Message.WParam%2A?displayProperty=fullName> values. Actual constant values can be found in the windows.h header file included in the Platform SDK (Core SDK section) download, which is also available on MSDN.
[!code-cs[System.Windows.Forms.Control.WndProc#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/m-system.windows.forms.m_5_1.cs)] [!code-vb[System.Windows.Forms.Control.WndProc#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/m-system.windows.forms.m_5_1.vb)] [!code-cpp[System.Windows.Forms.Control.WndProc#1](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/m-system.windows.forms.m_5_1.cpp)]
